title: GM the Modern Dinosaur
bodyText:
I recently went to see the footprints of dinosaurs in southern Korea. I could see a lot right beside the sea. The area has been converted into a theme park and a great variety of dinosaur models were on display.

It made me think of the time when they wandered around freely and ruled the planet. They were giant, numerous, invincible and were present on almost all continents. All this made me think about the great corporations of our time and specifically General Motors.

There is a great deal of similarity between GM and dinosaurs. Just like dinosaurs, GM was once a mighty corporation. It had operations around the world and was able to snuff out competition wherever it went because of its financial strength.

It produced various models that were quickly embraced by people. It was ahead of its time and various automobile innovations can be attributed to the research conducted by GM. But somewhere down the road that innovative and enterprising spirit changed to arrogance.

GM found out that instead of building modern, fuel-efficient and environment-friendly cars, it could influence the environment policy. Its executives dictated the standards set in Washington so that GM could sell more of its gas-guzzlers.

It was all going well until the time that Toyota in Japan and Hyundai in Korea started to think differently. They started making better and fuel-efficient cars. And soon efficient and durable cars from Toyota and Hyundai replaced the gas-guzzling, chrome-laden "Detroit iron."

GM on the other hand continued to be arrogant. They took pride in their financial strength and were sheltered by the protectionist policies of the American government. However, consumers all over the world started to shift toward the Japanese and Korean cars.

Although consumers are brand-conscious, they are usually very careful with their money. When they buy any automobile they seek efficiency and seek to minimize running costs. GM could not offer a better deal compared to Toyota or Hyundai. It could not read the pulse of its customers.

The dinosaurs were no different, they simply could not adapt when the external environment changed. As long as it was favourable they ruled the planet. But there was a problem.

The dinosaurs were cold-blooded, which meant that they could not regulate their body temperature. So as the external environment changed they could not survive. In the present day the only descendants of the dinosaurs can be found in the sky.

Only a few of the species developed wings and could migrate to a favorable climate. Adaptation is the key to survival, be it the biological world or the corporate world.

As we can see with GM and dinosaurs, that size does not guarantee success - it is efficiency and the ability to change that increases the probability of success. I remember Rick Wagoner, the ex-CEO of GM, appearing in an interview on TV few years ago.

He was asked the reason as to why GM is not building fuel-efficient cars. He simply replied that his research team had done a consumer survey and they build cars according to needs of the consumers. And according to them, consumers were willing to spend on fuel. They required bigger and apparently safer cars.

I think he saw safety in size. If size were so important then dinosaurs would definitely have outlived cockroaches. This statement clearly suggests a lack of vision on the part of the leader of such a behemoth. I welcome the decision by the American government to show him the door.

Although it is my belief that governments should not interfere in the matters of private corporations, in this case the government intervened as the majority shareholder and had every right to take such a decision.

The problem with all automakers is one of overcapacity. The projections predicting the strong growth in demand went haywire as a result of turmoil in the financial sector. As an automobile is a discretionary item, people stopped buying new cars.

The only way to overcome this demand destruction is either a reduction in production or finding new markets. This means immediate layoffs and selling unproductive assets. The best way forward for GM might be Chapter 11 bankruptcy. Then it can probably re-emerge from it leaner and more efficient.

Even the dinosaurs re-emerged as birds. They were small but efficient and could survive till today. So whenever someone tells me that this corporation is so big that it is completely insulated from any crisis, I ask them if they remember the dinosaurs.

title: The responsible enterprise -where citizenship and commerce meet -
bodyText:
Historically, many companies treated environment, social and governance (ESG) issues as important, but tangential to the core business.

Sometimes their motivation was a desire to be recognized as good corporate citizens. In other cases, ESG issues were viewed as compliance requirements, or perhaps good public relations.

But more often than not, these issues were managed as secondary activities with an indirect connection to the core business and bottom line.

All of that is changing. The market today is undergoing a significant shift, with companies increasingly expected to address ESG issues head on.

At the same time, many are recognizing both the tangible and intangible value of integrating these issues into core business activities. Commitment of human and financial capital to this area continues to grow, especially among companies that see clear impacts on their value chain.

In a recent Deloitte survey ('ESG survey') of 250 business executives about these issues, three drivers of ESG imperatives were identified: a need to bolster the corporate reputation and brand, increased regulatory scrutiny, and higher expectations from consumers and the broader community.

Most of the surveyed executives expect ESG issues to have a growing impact on their strategies, products and services, and operations over the next two years.

Not surprisingly, large companies (with more than $10 billion in revenue) foresee the greatest impact. These companies tend to operate across industries and geographies where the social and environmental issues are most acutely visible.

Another Deloitte survey found that two thirds of global CFOs expect their role in ESG-related strategies to increase over the next two years. This suggests that the ESG imperative is becoming a C-Suite issue and is expected to have a material impact on the bottom line.

What's driving this trend?

Five factors account for the accelerating growth of corporate interest in ESG issues ? none of which shows any sign of letup. A new era of the responsible enterprise appears to be here to stay.

¢´y Loss of trust: According to the 2012 Edelman Trust Barometer, public trust in business continues to decline, dropping to 45 percent in the United States, compared to 51 percent in 2010. Trust in government is even lower. These findings indicate a growing perception that large institutions are not serving the public interest well.

¢´y Stakeholder pressures: Pressure from consumers and investors is an important motivator for businesses to take action on ESG issues. Globally, this pressure is increasing, especially as the ranks of the middle class expand in emerging markets such as China and India. A wealthier and more educated middle class tends to have higher expectations for corporate ESG performance, as illustrated by growing protests against new factories in China. In addition, today's investors are increasingly concerned about short-term ESG risks and tend to reward companies that disclose more ESG information. The number of S&P 500 companies that issued sustainability reports jumped from 19 percent in 2010 to 53 percent in 2011 ? and is expected to continue rising.

¢´yNatural resources pressures: Growing global demand and supply constraints are generally pushing up prices for energy, agricultural products, and raw materials ? an upward trajectory punctuated by periods of extreme volatility. For example, precious metal prices have increased fourfold since 2005. Also, the recent U.S. drought, which affected nearly two-thirds of the contiguous states, was the worst in 60 years and drove up cereal prices by 17 percent. Such resource trends are increasingly top of mind for business leaders and managers. More than 70 percent of Deloitte's ESG survey respondents said their organizations were making a significant commitment to improved resource efficiency.

¢´y Supply chain pressures: Executives surveyed by Deloitte see a multitude of supply chain risks that directly affect their businesses, including climate adaptation, regulatory pressures, and the unethical practices of certain business partners. Companies rely on global supply chain networks that are largely beyond their immediate control, but those same companies are being held publicly accountable for the actions of those suppliers. Also, the strong emphasis that many companies have placed on supply chain efficiency often reduces the margin for error and makes supply chains more vulnerable to all forms of risk, including ESG risks. In recent years, companies have been hit by a number of major disruptions, including floods in Thailand, the tsunami in Japan, and labor unrest in China and South Africa. Disruptions such as these help explain why ESG survey respondents expect to commit more resources to mitigating environmental and social risks over the next two years. The increasing frequency and financial impact of these types of supply chain risks are not going unnoticed.

¢´y Social and mobile enablement: A Deloitte risk management survey of 192 U.S. executives found that social media ranks among the top five most important sources of risk. With social and mobile technologies becoming globally pervasive, questionable business practices have no place to hide.

Problems that in the past might have remained behind closed doors can now be exposed to the world in a few minutes without a lot of advanced technology ? then scrutinized in detail ? long after traditional media sources would have lost interest.

Lessons learned: What works and what doesn't

Many companies today are transforming their cultures to more strongly reflect ESG values and align them with their core mission and strategies.

They are actively measuring and mitigating ESG-related risks and improving transparency, using advanced analytics to improve reporting, perceptions, and management of environmental and social risks.

These companies are also aligning their business models with their environmental and social goals, and their performance management systems with desired outcomes.

Among the senior leaders we surveyed who work at companies that recognize the importance of environmental and social issues, 63 percent said they support changing compensation plans to reflect their ESG commitments.

Looking ahead, survey participants expect to commit more human and financial resources to ESG, not only to mitigate risk and improve transparency but also to change the organizational culture.

According to the executives surveyed, this commitment will require three crucial actions that are closely linked to the core business: clear articulation of the company's ESG goals and values to all stakeholders; improved alignment of the ESG strategy with the overall company mission; and a demonstrated business case for investment in ESG initiatives.

These actions can boost a company's competitiveness by making it more attractive to investment capital and top talent in a global marketplace that is increasingly conscious of ESG issues and risks.

Looking ahead

Aligning ESG issues and corporate citizenship with commerce can help companies create shareholder value in three measurable ways: pinch, push, and shift.

Pinch. Downside risks should be reduced or 'pinched', especially in a global marketplace that is increasingly volatile, resource-constrained, and socially engaged.

One way to do this is by integrating ESG and financial reporting, which can increase transparency, improve understanding of ESG risks, and help drive targeted mitigation strategies.

Improved transparency can also help build trust with customers, investors, and employees, creating a halo effect that makes it easier for a company to earn forgiveness when things go wrong, while getting more credit for things it is doing right.

Companies can also leverage social and environmental issues to create new product and service innovations that drive revenue and reduce operating costs.

Deloitte's research on innovation shows that leaders on ESG issues are over 400 percent more likely to be considered innovation leaders.

For example, Nike's Considered Design initiative has enabled the company to recycle 82 million plastic bottles into high-performance sportswear, reduce waste by 19 percent in its footwear business, increase the use of environmentally preferred materials by 20 percent, and achieve a 95 percent reduction in volatile organic compounds.

In addition, our ESG survey shows that 32 percent of senior executives expect more than 5 percent of future annual revenue growth to come from products and services that reduce environmental and social impacts, while another 32 percent expect 1 to 5 percent of future annual revenue growth to come from those same kinds of sources.

Shift. Weaving ESG factors into the fabric of a company can improve shareholder value over time by permanently shifting the expected share price to a higher level, creating a valuation premium. Part of this shift comes from pinch and push, which strengthen a company's brand, reduce risk, and fuel innovation.

Another part comes from improved operating efficiency and reduced waste, which can significantly reduce costs and increase profitability.

In addition, a strategic approach to ESG issues can boost a company's value by helping to attract financial and human capital.

Responsible enterprises attract more funding and enjoy a lower cost of equity capital than their less responsible counterparts.

They also have an easier time attracting talent, especially younger workers, who tend to be particularly conscious of social and environmental issues. These effects can help create a lasting competitive advantage.

The increasing focus on ESG issues is a long-term trend, driven by rising public awareness and concerns about adaptation to a changing business environment, income disparity, and quality of life around the world.

Companies that are further along the journey toward effective integration of ESG issues into risk management approaches, business operations, and strategy will likely be in a stronger position to compete in the future.

In particular, they will likely have the benefit of being able to take a strategic and measured approach when responding to stakeholder pressures and environmental crises.

On the other hand, companies that continue to treat ESG issues merely as compliance could be missing an opportunity to be rewarded for the good work they do, making it harder to attract the customers, talent, and capital that are crucial to value creation.

title: [Green Growth:Korea`s New Strategy (55)] Should rich countries pay for climate change
bodyText:
The following is the 55th in a series of articles focusing on the Korean government's "green growth" strategy. The series will also introduce the increasing efforts of major advanced countries to promote a green economy. - Ed.

The world's climate is changing for the worse due to human activities. If world temperatures reach a certain threshold, an irreversible climate shift may occur, with grave consequences for world biodiversity and ecological balance. Precise consequences are unknown but could be catastrophic for much of humanity. And just to be clear, no insurance program exists to bail the world out should the worst case scenario materialize.

Options for facing climate change include curbs on the accumulation of greenhouse gas emissions into the atmosphere, adjustment to climate change, and hoping for the best until uncertainties abate. Most scientists believe the best option today is to curb new accumulation of greenhouse gases, and proactively reduce their concentrations "to make up for lost time."

Adjusting to climate change - with our current understanding of its dangers - may not be feasible in many places on the planet. Hoping for the best, again with our understanding of potential consequences and their irreversibility, would be irresponsible.

Much of recent debate on climate change has involved strategies for emission reduction, or active removal of greenhouse gases. Scientists search for the most cost-effective techniques to achieve these goals. Costs of the currently available techniques are fairly well known. They represent a setback to economic growth, but relative to the potential dangers of climate change the costs are bearable. But who should pay?

Governments in many industrialized countries have stepped up to the plate with various public efforts and market stimuli under the "green growth" header. They have pledged to jointly spend hundreds of billions of dollars annually on promoting energy efficiency, clean energy sources and sustainable management of resources. Coordinated efforts and information-sharing programs among industrialized and developing countries have sprung up.

Unfortunately, these voluntary efforts have not been sufficient, and have been hampered by disagreements regarding how emission reduction and its costs should be distributed across industries and countries.

Disagreements stem from considerations for equity, as well as for the competitiveness of businesses that undertake emission reductions compared to unregulated businesses, in the same or other industries. Furthermore, options for mitigation of climate change are numerous, and their viability differs across industries and countries.

To ensure that emission reductions take place at cost effective sites, all countries should coordinate their efforts. Furthermore, when environmental initiatives are undertaken, their funding crowds out other public or private programs dealing with other societal ills. These opportunity costs of environmental efforts are not fully certain, and vary significantly across countries. Again, coordination among all countries is warranted to ensure that emission reduction takes place at cost effective sites.

Finally, if future scientific evidence shows that CO2 is not exactly uniformly diffused - so that damages from CO2 would depend on its source - location of emission abatement may matter.

Regardless of efficiency considerations, determining how the global bill should be split is imperative from the viewpoint of fairness. Even in this respect there is much disagreement. The differential responsibility for climate change mitigation could be assigned based on a number of criteria.

The following are just a few criteria that may be applied:

Historic contribution to the cumulative GHG concentrations in the atmosphere - this most commonly quoted criterion is meaningful to the extent that people should be held accountable for actions of their forefathers.

Contribution of past emissions to the countries' stage of development - to the extent that the current generation in some countries has benefitted from pollution more than the current generation in other countries, the former should compensate the latter.

Countries' current ability to pay, in terms of aggregate or per capita income - richer countries can more easily afford to provide funds to environmental initiatives.

The above criteria are in line with the "stock" notions of equity, as they consider the cumulative effect of past evolution and the up-to-date state of affairs. They may or may not be based on the volume of countries' pillaging of the environment in the past.

Other criteria, based on "flow" notions of equity, could be based on countries' current and future behavior:

The country's current emissions - since we have recognized the danger of GHG emissions only recently, only new emissions should be tallied, as they are made in disregard of the known environmental impacts.

Similarly, countries' emissions per unit of national output may be a criterion - to the extent that some nations are more wasteful of environmental resources in their production processes, they may be asked to pay for their excesses.

Finally, the country's anticipated damages incurred from climate change - to the extent that some countries stand to lose more from rising oceans, extreme fluctuations in weather and precipitation, and diminished biodiversity, they may be expected to shoulder more costs of mitigation. Incidentally, developing nations tend to be located at lower latitudes, facing higher risks and damages under climate change. Under the cynical principle that those affected most should pay, developing nations may be expected to contribute more.

Existing differences across nations

Countries around the world differ in the stock of available technologies, and size and composition of their industrial base. Countries rely on various industries for economic sustenance, and have different energy portfolios (Refer to Figure 1). Globalization has allowed industries to distribute themselves across world regions, and as a result, economic activity and energy intensity of production vary significantly by geography (Figure 2). For these reasons, countries are predisposed to certain CO2 emission patterns, and their costs of emission abatement vary.

Countries around the world differ in the rate of population and economic growth (Figure 3). Demographic trends and the process of economic catch up are responsible for a large amount of variation in countries' emission patterns (Figure 4). In 2008, China became the top emitter of CO2 from electricity generation, followed by the United States and Europe. China emits over a fifth of all GHG emissions in the world. Nevertheless, per capita emissions in Australia, the United States and Canada (10 tons per person per year) are still nearly four times those in China (2.4 tons), and three times those in Europe (3.3 tons).

Current pledges on climate change mitigation

In light of the present and past differences across countries, and both the efficiency and equity considerations, most countries are moving toward a consensus on a coordinated global plan. Under the 1997 Kyoto Protocol, industrialized nations are obliged to meet their GHG limitations by reducing emissions, purchasing carbon credits, or arranging for emission reductions in other countries. Industrialized nations also pledge to support emissions abatement in developing nations through financial and technical assistance.

Environmental initiatives have also sprung up among developing countries. The Asia Pacific Partnership on Clean Development and Climate is a pact among seven Asia-Pacific nations (jointly responsible for over 50 percent of global CO2 emissions), both industrialized and developing, to cooperate on the issues of energy demand, green technologies and pollution.

In Korea, the Ministry of Knowledge Economy has pledged over 130 trillion won over the next two decades on cleaner energy sources, renewable energy technologies and energy efficiency. China plans to spend over $200 billion on energy efficiency, renewables, public transport, upgrading of the energy grid and other pollution-related programs over the next five years.

At the same time, developing countries do not want to forsake economic growth or their competitiveness. Russia, fearing an economic slowdown, has so far not committed to emission abatement, and is evaluating climate adaptation strategies.

Other developing countries have lobbied for greater financial and technology transfers from rich countries. Gao Guangsheng, the director general of China's Office of National Coordination on Climate Change, has asked rich countries for 1 percent of their gross domestic product annually to build scientific and regulatory capacity, adopt energy-efficient technologies and conserve resources in developing nations.

This 1 percent should be in addition to the industrialized countries' own emission abatement obligations. China's position is that industrialized countries have an "unshirkable" responsibility to "provide new, additional, adequate, and predictable resources" for emission reduction programs in developing nations, while protecting poorer countries' right to development. China also insists on maintaining the designation of developed and developing countries from the Kyoto protocol regardless of future development, and regardless of the composition and energy-intensity of their industries.

Green policy v. green bills

From the perspective of efficiency, emission abatement in developing countries may cost less than in industrialized countries, because making the construction of new cities and industries more environmentally friendly may be cheaper than retrofitting existing stock in the developed world. Industrialized nations can also better afford to clean up pollution, and can afford to pay developing nations to do the same - now.

Economist Nicholas Stern reported to the British prime minister and chancellor of the exchequer that if action was taken today, the cost of avoiding serious climate change may be around 1-2 percent of world GDP. That is affordable for industrialized nations, particularly compared to the cost of more drastic reductions down the road if business-as-usual emissions continue for the next 20-40 years (4-5 percent of world GDP).

Politically, showing a bit of goodwill could be beneficial for industrialized nations in the sphere of political, economic and scientific cooperation. Finally, from the perspective of fairness, the motive is perhaps strongest. Industrialized nations have been decimating the environment for nearly 200 years, and are responsible for 70 percent of the existing stock of atmospheric greenhouse gases. Developing nations, on the other hand, started to contribute to climate change only about 40 years ago. Industrialized nations have seized most benefits from their pillage of the environment, while the dangers of climate change now accrue to all nations indiscriminately.

However, from the efficiency point of view, benefits to industrialized nations of spending money in developing nations is lower than spending domestically. Domestic spending spurs job creation, investment and consumption, spilling over to other sectors and propping up the entire domestic economy. These direct and multiplier effects of spending domestically exceed the would-be direct benefits of spending in developing countries.

Politically, giving money to other countries may be unpopular with voters, particularly during an economic slump. For one, offering companies in developing nations subsidies to up their compliance with environmental standards may give them advantage over more regulated businesses in rich countries. In China, a quarter of emissions come from production for exports to developed nations.

Even when money is given to domestic companies to improve environmental conditions in the developing world - such as through cleaning up operations of their supply chains in offshore locations - this would not be a cost-effective contribution to the "Green New Deal" as long as regulators do not oversee the environmental compliance of all contractors in the developing world.

Pollution may also be viewed as an "internal issue" that developing countries could combat themselves. According to some estimates, pollution costs China 8-12 percent of its $1.4 trillion GDP in direct damages (to health, agriculture, forests and buildings). One could expect developing nations to deal with such "uneconomic growth" on their own.

Furthermore, concurring with the request for assistance may set a dangerous precedent for the organization and funding of many environmental initiatives in developing countries. Developing countries may stall their initiatives, and their capacity for self-organization and own financing may vanish.

China insists that assistance under the U.N. Framework Convention on Climate Change should be treated separately from other financial and technology transfers. This refusal to deal with the West in good faith forebodes future disputes regarding rich countries' responsibilities and China's rights under the deal. The country may face a moral hazard motive to limit its achievements under the present deal to procure additional funding for stricter environmental targets in the future.

Finally, philosophically speaking, the compensation of developing countries may be beside the point, because developing countries have themselves benefitted from the early development in industrialized nations. For one, they benefitted through trade, foreign direct investment, outsourcing, humanitarian aid etc. Two, they enjoy technologies that came about through decades of exploration in the industrialized world.

Distinguishing nations that have benefitted from the long, environmentally-detrimental development from countries that have not is less than straightforward. Furthermore, some developing countries have also had their jab at unfettered industrialization, and should perhaps be held responsible.

Energy-intensive metallurgy was used in China nearly a millennium before it took off in the West. This commerce led to extensive deforestation, and burning of charcoal and coal. For centuries, China's level of development was above that in Europe. Whether global environmental degradation has its origin only in the 19th century, and whether the current stage of development is the only one that matters are philosophical questions.

Time to act

Dealing with climate change presents great challenges to theoretical economists and policy makers alike. Important economic factors differ across countries; the past and present are characterized by utter inequality; and the future is veiled in uncertainty. Effective policy is paralyzed by stakeholders' "what if" musings about the past as well as about the future. The debate on what should be done and by whom has business-sense, ethical, as well as philosophical facets.

Attempting to point fingers is tricky given how technologies and our understanding of the environmental dangers have evolved over time. Even from the simple principle of efficiency, uncertainty about future innovations, CO2 abatement costs, and damages from climate change make it difficult to find solutions. Existing institutions, regulations, and barriers on international flows of resources add to the complexity.

Ultimately, countries must bridge their differences, even if it calls for big compromises. In spite of all the issues, a broad consensus among the world's top emitters of greenhouse gases and a decisive action are urgently needed.

All countries must reduce CO2 emissions by 15-20 percent from the 1990 level by year 2020 and at least by 50 percent by 2050 to eschew major changes in global climate. Industrialized as well as developing countries must start cooperating in good faith right away.

The good news is that cross-country variation in the opportunity costs of cleaning up allows countries to exploit comparative advantages. Acting today will also avoid greater costs later.

Finally, countries that fear they will share too high a cost today may be reassured by goodwill that exists among countries. The 20th century has seen a good record of voluntary assistance programs around the world and remembrance of good deeds.

title: What is Green Climate Fund?
bodyText:
The Green Climate Fund is a new international financial institution dedicated to the fight against climate change.

The idea behind it is simple: Rich countries put money into the fund â€• they have pledged to raise $100 billion a year by 2020 â€• which will then be directed to poor countries to support their climate adaptation and mitigation plans.

The GCF officially launched at the 2011 U.N. Climate Change Conference in Durban, South Africa, and is currently governed by a board of 24 members and an interim secretariat.

The first meeting of the board was held in Geneva in August this year and elected Zaheer Fakir of South Africa and Ewen McDonald of Australia as its two co-chairs for one year.

The next meeting is due in Songdo from Oct. 18-20, where the location of the fund's headquarters is expected to be decided.

It is envisioned to support projects, programs, policies and other activities in developing countries, but most of the key details, including how to raise and distribute funds, are yet to be drawn up.

title: Adaptation critical in changing climate
bodyText:
From a climate change perspective, adaptation is precautionary or anticipatory adjustments to shifts already happening or likely to happen in the near future.

From a climate change perspective, adaptation is precautionary or anticipatory adjustments to shifts already happening or likely to happen in the near future. Accelerated climate change and increasing variability is one of the greatest challenges we face. The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) has determined that there is clear evidence that human actions are exacerbating the natural variability of the climate system; we are responsible for producing changes. Though there is general agreement that there is an urgent need to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, there is also recognition that we will have to adapt to the changes that will be driven by the emissions already loaded into the atmosphere. There seems little likelihood of an international agreement to reduce emissions before 2020, meaning that climate change could be further accelerated. There is a possibility that we will enter an era of dangerous climate change where extreme events could severely threaten communities and livelihoods throughout the world or even cause irreversible damage to ecosystems. Adaptation is an urgent need. Climate change risks Broadly speaking accelerated climate change risks are meteorological in nature, for example temperatures will rise and droughts and floods are likely to be more severe and less predictable. Table 1 highlights some of the possible risks that we will face. The lack of an international agreement to limit emissions means that many of the impacts listed in Table 1 are likely to be exacerbated. This will make adaptation even more challenging. It is very probable that we will have to adapt to significant changes. We may have already reached tipping points that could lead to irreversible change. A tipping point is where warming, for example, of the tundra releases methane into the atmosphere. Methane is a powerful greenhouse gas and this would further accelerate the warming trend. It is clear that adaptation is needed urgently. Adaptation is a process of adjustment to disruptive events. It is not a new concept. Societies have adjusted continually throughout history. From a climate change perspective, adaptation is precautionary or anticipatory adjustment(s) to shifts already happening or likely to happen in the near future. It is defined by IPCC in its Third Assessment Report as: 'Adjustment in natural or human systems is in response to actual or expected climatic stimuli or their effects, which moderates harm or exploits beneficial opportunities. Various types of adaptation can be distinguished, including anticipatory and reactive adaptation, private and public adaptation, and autonomous and planned adaptation.' (IPCC, 2001) Adaptation is not just adjustment to an average climate condition but is a response to reduce vulnerability to extremes, variability, and rates of change at all scales. Though the aim of adaptation is to reduce or mitigate vulnerability, its focus is on adaptive capacity, which is the ability of our societies to adjust to climate disruptions. Vulnerability is the degree to which societies are unable to cope with the adverse effects of climate change, including climate variability and extremes. Adaptive capacity refers to the potential or ability of communities to adapt to the effects or impacts of climate change and is the ability of societies to adjust to actual or expected climate stresses, or to cope with the consequences. The determinants of adaptive capacity comprise factors such as wealth, technology, education, information, skills, infrastructure, access to resources, government and stability and management capabilities. Wealthier nations have greater adaptive capacity than poorer nations. A term increasingly used in adaptation is resilience, which is the ability of communities to respond and cope with disruptive events. This means building up the capacity of communities to be more self-reliant. Resilience is a function of learning from experience and using the determinants of adaptive capacity to better prepare for future. In this sense resilience is an on-going process. This is an important aspect of adaptation to climate change as we will have constantly assess climate hazards and make judgements about the risks that they will produce. Adaptation strategies Adaptation strategies will differ from place to place. There is no single solution. Adaptation strategies should aim at reducing risks to communities, promoting food and water security, protecting critical infrastructure and ensuring that people are prepared. The types of measures that can be used can be characterized in two ways. The first are structural measures which comprise any physical construction to reduce or avoid possible impacts of hazards, or application of engineering techniques to achieve hazard-resistance and resilience in structures or systems such as flood levies, ocean wave barriers and evacuation shelters. The second are non-structural measures which comprise any measure that does not involve physical construction but uses knowledge, practice or agreement to reduce risks and impacts, in particular through policies and laws, public awareness raising, training and education. Common non-structural measures include building codes, land-use planning laws and their enforcement, research and assessment, information resources, and public awareness programs. Local knowledge, climate science Short measures can range from the building of flood defences through to the introduction of drought resistant crops. It is important that adaptation measures should build on local knowledge as well as good climate science. There needs to be an interchange of information of what works best and why. It will be through learning that adaptation measures will build resilience. But there are likely to be some very difficult decisions to make. Many of our cities and critical infrastructure are in coastal areas and highly vulnerable to sea level rise and storms. New Orleans is a graphic example of what may happen. Even today there is discussion of whether some of the low-lying areas of the city should be re-developed. In the future we will have to consider whether or not to abandon some areas, as the costs of defending are likely to be prohibitive. In Asia there are many cities that will be threatened by rising sea levels and extreme storms. Countries such as Bangladesh will lose land and many will be displaced. This raises the prospect of climate refugees. How will we deal with such problems? Costs of Adaptation This is a contentious area. A study by Stern in 2006 on the economics of climate change concluded that it would more cost effective to act now as opposed to dealing the consequences. Stern suggests that a spending of roughly 3-5 percent of GDP would avoid the some 15-20 percent of GDP if we did nothing (Stern, 2006). Studies in 2007 from UNDP (UN Development Programme) and Oxfam estimated costs between $50 and $109 billion per annum (Oxfam, 2007; UNDP, 2007). The UN Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) estimated that total funding need for adaptation by 2030 could amount to between $49 and $171 billion per annum globally, of which $27 and $66 billion would accrue in developing countries (UNFCCC, 2007). More recent analysis suggests that these figures underestimate the costs. Adaptation is complex and studies need to include a number of sectors, such as agriculture, water, ecosystems, coastal systems, human health and infrastructure. An analysis by Parry et al (2009) of the UNFCCC study, suggest that in some sectors estimates may need to be 2 or 3 times higher.A 2010 study by the World Bank into the infrastructure costs alone suggests an annual spend between $75 and $100 billion (World Bank 2010). One of the problems is deciding on what areas and sectors to protect. This implies that a concerted effort is likely to be much higher that current published estimates. Given that the recent World Bank study only focuses on infrastructure then it is not unreasonable to assume that a comprehensive approach is likely to exceed $100 billion per annum. Cost and lives According to The Global Humanitarian Forum (2010) the costs of climate related losses amount to $125 billion per annum and some 300,000 lives are lost every year along with countless numbers of lives that have been degraded because of climate change. It is impossible to put a value on such losses and suffering. But whatever the costs we should note that the IMF estimates that the costs of the global credit crunch are some $10 trillion. Through UNFCCC the global community has established the Green Climate Fund which has identified that developed countries should commit to providing $30 billion in fast-start finance for developing countries in 2010-12 and to mobilize $100 billion a year in public and private finance by 2020 for adaptation and low carbon initiatives. Don't hold your breath as the global economic slowdown may mean that this commitment will not be fully met. Climate adaptation is urgent. However there does seem to be a lack of action. This is odd as adaptation is about protecting people and the assets we need. Many of the measure will require innovation, a move to a greener economy. This will have benefits as new products will be needed. This can have long term benefits, particularly if we decide to adapt the global energy system to new and alternative energy resources. What is clear is that many of the options are realisable. The question remains: do we have the political will? It seems that many of our leaders are transfixed Giddens Paradox (2009); they will not act until something goes wrong. Dr. Geoff O'Brien is a Senior Lecturer in Geography and Environmental Management at Northumbria University in Britain. He combines engineering practice with social science work on policy together with a strong sense of business culture. Prior to joining Northumbria University, Dr. O'Brien was involved in the geophysical industry with a global remit with a particular focus on environmental responsibility. On leaving the geophysical industry he undertook an MBA at Durham University in Britain with the intent of starting a green business.
